Few of the Tory fallen at the 1997 general election lost more sadly than Rhodes Boyson. The most dedicated and professional of constituency MPs was ejected from the conventionally safe seat of Brent North, north-west London, with a swing of 18.8%. In fact, as neighbouring scores indicated, there was nothing personal about it. Fears that the partial closing of Edgware general hospital would become complete produced local fury and the Conservatives' terrible election results.

To a casual observer, Boyson, who has died aged 87, had been a reactionary favouring the death penalty and not favouring homosexuals. This was literally true, and was accentuated by a conscious dressing for the part of a Dickensian heavy, with waistcoats and whiskers and a grumbling style of address which suggested a pedagogue lightly balancing a supple, therapeutic rattan cane.

But Boyson was much more than this. A brilliantly successful headteacher with high academic credentials from four universities – "proper universities" he would have called them – Cardiff, Manchester, LSE and Cambridge, he was an early critic of educational standards whose extreme views of 1970 became Conservative practice in the late 80s and were largely adopted by Labour subsequently. The thunder he liked to roll hid a large vein of kindness, and as the Tory party moved to the right, he came to look like a crypto-moderate, certainly a force for stability.

Boyson was born in Haslingden, Lancashire, the son of William and Bertha Boyson. His father was a Labour alderman cotton-spinner and conscientious objector. After having sat as a Labour councillor (1957-61), Rhodes became a Tory, not out of reaction to his father, but as an almost pre-emptive rejection of the 60s. A Methodist, he had most of the old nonconformist assumptions – belief in work and sexual austerity – to which a spell in the Royal Navy had added a nationalism and military sympathy not associated with the chapel. The cliche runs "to the right of Genghis Khan": Boyson, much more interestingly, stood rightwards of John Bright, the 19th-century Liberal MP and strong anti-Corn Law advocate of free trade.

As an educationist, Boyson was alienated by that 60s shift from hard subjects to soft, examinations to no examinations, grammar and spelling to not grammar and spelling. Having gone on from Haslingden grammar school to obtain an MA from Manchester and a PhD from the LSE, with a thesis on the Corn Laws, and having, over 24 years, first taught, then taken three headships, concluding at Highbury Grove, Islington, north London (1967-74), he was a convinced traditionalist with exam results used to validate tradition.

The success of Highbury Grove, marked in a book succinctly titled Oversubscribed (1974), expressed in action Boyson's antipathy to the experimental, child-centred schooling of the 60s. Ironically, Margaret Thatcher, with a career to make under Ted Heath, did more in the way of liquidating grammar schools than anyone including the policy's deviser, Anthony Crosland. Boyson disliked compulsory comprehensives – "a dangerous neurotic desire for change" – but was determined to make his comprehensive work, and on any fair count he did.

Boyson, with characteristic cussedness, also managed to play the media. Television at the time tended to favour fashionably leftwards thinking, and Boyson doubtless seemed a good candidate to be a butt for it. Instead, as a regular advocate of a coherent hard line on education, he was so memorable and effective as to become a figure of national recognition.

The heavily stressed Lancashire accent and downright manner marked him off as a "character". But he was also winning arguments, and, with the publication of the first Black Papers, joined a formidable group with John Marks, AE (Tony) Dyson and CB (Brian) Cox, fighting a battle for which the Conservative party lacked the nerve or conviction.

In fairness, Boyson, with his working-class roots and own scholastic achievements, truly cared for good education and knew exactly what he was talking about. But he would find the Tory party opportunistic and indifferent to rigour and standards.

He sat on Waltham Forest council from 1968, and fought the hopeless Eccles constituency, in Lancashire, in 1970. Three years later he was chosen for the new Brent North seat and entered parliament at the age of 48, in the February 1974 election that Edward Heath's Conservative government lost.

When Thatcher led the Tories back to power in 1979, Boyson was at an age at which middle-ranking ministers going no higher are usually discarded. Instead, Boyson began an eight-year career via junior office at education (1979-83) to minister at social security (1983-84), Northern Ireland (1984-86) and local government (1986-87).

His time on the frontbench had got off to an ill-fated start. As deputy education spokesman (1976-79), it seemed he was the victim either of a delicate sense of humour or, since this was Thatcher, total imperception, and was harnessed with Norman St John-Stevas, later Lord St John of Fawsley, who died earlier this year. There was a beautiful symmetry in their relationship – intelligent, cultivated men of contrasting types, they hated one another. Whereas Boyson was plain, blunt, spade-fancying north of England, puritan and solid with a rhetorical flourish, Stevas was mostly the opposite, though himself with a liking for flourishes that could obscure the serious with the frivolous.

More to the point, because Stevas accepted the Crosland line, little changed, and Boyson's time as parliamentary undersecretary was frustrating and a disappointment. So was Thatcher, for whom he had been an early fugleman.

She, having accepted comprehensives as part of Heath's general falling in with Labour thinking, contented herself largely with making the right noises on education. The great push for the core curriculum and a critical assessment of schools and teachers came towards the end of her time in office, with Kenneth Baker's Education Reform Act of 1988, and continued under the less rightwing John Major.

Boyson was never trusted with the job he coveted – radical restorer of the education system. Partly this was because Thatcher was not sufficiently interested in the subject to want early, vigorous solutions. The voucher scheme which he had ardently favoured was killed off in 1983.

He saw his Northern Ireland job as a dumping ground. But he had been his own worst enemy. A fine conversational debater on TV or in symposiums, he was never effective in the Commons, tending to be slightly disorganised, giving clumsy speeches delivered without impact.

Generally, his rightwingness was of the wholesome kind, and he supported a ban on contracting companies with any discriminatory employment practice. As member for a racially mixed constituency, he made himself known and helpful to all communities.

On the backbenches after 1987, the year in which he was knighted, he was a dangerous enemy, as John Moore discovered when he was secretary of state for social services. The fall of Moore, once a Tory crown prince, began when the proposed rejig of social security ran up against a Boyson-led group which saw it penalising constituents with some savings.

But then Boyson looked sedulously after his constituents. Steady Labour voters were impressed, though not converted, to get congratulations on a child's GCSE results through the door within days of them appearing. Boyson's actual downfall was the product of a policy he had resisted: the closing down of parts of Edgware general hospital, something delightful to the planners and detestable to the voters of Brent and Harrow.

In 1994, he appeared on Have I Got News for You and seemed not to appreciate the lighthearted nature of the programme. Still undaunted by the notion of satire, three years later he took part in Chris Morris's Brass Eye, and was also an early interviewee of Ali G.

Boyson was more intelligent than he was shrewd, and, reactionary grumbles aside, he was a kind, companionable man, and excellent company.

He married Violet Burletson in 1946, and they had two daughters. After their divorce in 1971, he married Florette MacFarlane, a teacher.

• Rhodes Boyson, teacher and politician, born 11 May 1925; died 28 August 2012

• This article was amended on 31 August 2012. It had omitted mention of the passing of the Education Reform Act 1988 while Margaret Thatcher was still prime minister. This has been corrected.

• This article was further amended on 6 September 2012. In editing, CB Cox, one of the authors of the Black Papers, had been wrongly identified as Caroline Cox; he was in fact Brian Cox. This has been corrected.

The head of the first UK university to lose its right to admit students from outside the EU says its punishment for immigration failures has sent fear through other universities and will damage the UK "brand" abroad.

Malcolm Gillies, vice-chancellor of London Metropolitan University, said he was consulting lawyers on the issue as universities across the UK tried to find alternative places for up to 2,700 international students who will not be allowed to start or complete their courses there. They face removal from the UK unless they can find somewhere to study within 60 days.

"This sends a fear through many universities in a way that I think is going to be detrimental to their confidence as higher education institutions but also the projection of brand UK abroad," he told the Guardian.

Responses from other universities included "commiseration, worry, anger, but also a feeling of probably, 'well thank God it wasn't us this time'," Gillies said. "I think that shows the nervousness that many in the sector have, especially at a time when clearly government policy is changing but also when the UK Border Agency (UKBA) guidelines have been changing very rapidly."

Gillies has warned that the future of the 30,000-student university is at risk. Five hundred private higher education colleges have already lost their power to recruit abroad following crackdowns on bogus students.

The immigration minister, Damian Green, said London Met had displayed a "serious systemic failure" to know whether its students had the right to be in the UK in the first place. He denied making the university a political football over immigration controls and insisted such action would not be replicated across the university sector.

The UK's lucrative higher education business in international students involves about 300,000 students and is worth an estimated £5bn a year to the economy.

Green, speaking on the BBC's Today programme, said people entering Britain as students but seeking work exploited "one of the biggest loopholes in the immigration system".

UKBA audits of London Met found that more than a quarter of cases sampled had no leave to remain in Britain. There was also no proof that "a significant proportion" of international students had satisfactory English. In more than half of cases, the university did not know whether students were turning up to lectures or not.

Green said "any of these three breaches would be serious" and that it was important to ensure "not just private colleges but universities obey the law".

"What we found here is a serious systemic failure where it appears that the university doesn't have the capacity to be a proper sponsor [of international students] and to have confidence that the students have the right to be here in the first place," Green said.

University funders and leaders said the first priority was to sort out the future of genuine students. It is understood the Higher Education Funding Council for England and London Met have been in talks for weeks over the crisis, which began when the UKBA suspended the university's right to be a "highly trusted sponsor" of students on 16 July.

Gillies said the decision, which was taken because of what he called a "small minority" among international students not having "accurate documentation to remain in the UK", will leave a £30m hole in London Met's finances – nearly a fifth of its annual budget. The crisis had already cost "way over" £10m. Gillies said it would also cost the wider London economy £75m.

Gillies said 20-30 universities were already offering to help resettle students. "It's hard to think of a time that could have been worse [for this decision] because the suspension has done such damage already to our requirement for this coming year."

Efforts to find alternative places for affected students could prove difficult – even if they have appropriate visas. Most universities will have finalised their international student numbers for the new academic year.

The university may also face legal action from students who have paid up to £13,500 a year for uncompleted courses.

London Met will not be able to take extra students from Britain and the EU to make up the numbers and shore up its finances either. In England, for example, due to the need to control the costs of student loans, the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills sets a limit on the number of home and EU students that can be recruited. Given the high demand from home students, universities recruit right up to that limit, and then determine the number of places available to non-EU international students.

Prof Eric Thomas, the president of Universities UK, said the organisation was committed to eliminating any abuse of the student visa system, but that there were alternative ways of addressing UKBA's concerns and revocation of a university's licence should only be a decision of last resort. "We will be working with UKBA to ensure that compliance issues can be addressed in a more constructive way in the future," Thomas said.

Syed Rumman, vice-president for education for London Met's student union, accused the government of "chucking students' lives into the bin". Nine of the 10 union officers, including all five sabbatical officers, are international students, and like others face administrative removal in 60 days if they do not find other higher education institutions to offer them a place.

Liam Burns, president of the National Union of Students, said: "It is disgusting that international students continue to be used as a political football by politicians who seem either incapable of understanding, or are simply uncaring about, the impact of their decisions on individuals, universities and the UK economy.

"This decision will create panic and potential heartbreak for students not just at London Met but also all around the country."

Geoffrey Alderman of the Association of Independent Higher Education Providers said: "No one is gloating over this. It is sending shockwaves through the university sector but if half the concern had been shown at the draconian action of the UK Border Agency against non-taxpayer-funded higher education, the sympathy would be much greater.

"A lot of bogus institutions had to be cleared out of the system but in the course of this the baby has been thrown out with the bathwater."

London Met has set up a helpline for worried students – +44 (0) 20 7133 4141 – and the UKBA has posted advice for students online.

James Antle: 'Ryan galvanized the conservative base without frightening swing voters'

For much of the night, it appeared that convention planners had deliberately designed a snooze-fest intended to make Paul Ryan's acceptance speech look better.

The painfully unfunny Tim Pawlenty, the achingly dull Rob Portman, and depressingly banal John Thune all emerged to remind us they wouldn't have been better vice-presidential picks than Ryan. John McCain took the stage to lament the wars he didn't get to start after losing the 2008 presidential election, fervently hoping Mitt Romney will make up for lost time. Republicans you have never heard of enjoyed their 15 minutes of fame, though it often seemed much longer.

In the early going, the only positive moments were an artfully done (even if foreign policy-free) video tribute to Ron Paul, a cautious but well-received address by his son Rand Paul, and George HW Bush doing an impression of Dana Carvey doing an impression of him. (If you're curious, the 41st president nailed it.)

But as the program moved toward prime time, the speakers picked up the pace. Mike Huckabee started slow, as if Romney's censors had edited out the former Arkansas governor's charm. But his attack on the Obama administration's HHS contraceptive mandate was powerful, and his attempt to rally evangelicals behind a Mormon and a Catholic was sincere. Condoleezza Rice gave one of the strongest speeches of the convention. Susana Martinez, the first-term governor of New Mexico, was likeable, down-to-earth, and impressive.

Paul Ryan, nevertheless, remained the star of the show. Ryan is still honing his skills as a big event speaker and attack dog, but he did a good job delivering some of the most effective and specific anti-Obama barbs heard yet in Tampa.

"College grads shouldn't have to live out their 20s in childhood bedrooms, staring up at fading Obama posters," he zinged. "There is no shortage of words from the White House. What is missing is leadership from the White House," was another good Ryan line. Finally, on Barack Obama's tendency to blame his predecessors: "The man assumed office nearly four years ago. Isn't it time he assumed responsibility?"

You could quibble with some facts: the GM plant Ryan mentioned actually closed down before Obama took office, though Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has pointed out that the president said he would save it. The line itself serves as a reminder that Ryan himself voted for the auto bailout. But overall, Ryan did what he needed to: he galvanized the conservative base without frightening swing voters, all while amplifying the ticket's attack on Obama's economic policies.

The biggest blunder of the night was spending so much time reliving George W Bush's presidency. Bush himself appeared in an innocuous video. McCain channeled Bush on steroids. And for all Rice's rhetorical talent, she was essentially promoting warmed-over Bushism and a revisionist take on the 43rd president's "forward strategy of freedom", which didn't grapple with the general failure of his foreign policy in the Middle East.

Romney and Ryan should want to get clear of Bush.

James Antle is editor of the Daily Caller News Foundation

Michael Cohen: 'Ryan's speech was a good example of just how far the GOP has strayed from the truth'

Listening to Paul Ryan's vice-presidential speech this evening, I think I came within an inch of having a full-blown aneurysm. Never have I heard a major political speech so brazenly and stunningly dishonest. Others will want to talk about Ryan's strong performance and the wild crowd reaction from the assembled GOP delegates, but I'll just spend a few minutes chronicling his cavalcade of lies.

Ryan began with a doozy: implicitly blaming Obama for the closing of a General Motors plant in his town of Janesville, Wisconsin. First, that plant was closed when George W Bush was still president. (In fact, here's a press release from Ryan decrying the closure in June 2008, six months before Obama took office.) So, in a sense, Ryan was complaining that Obama didn't re-open it – a fairly amazing charge from a candidate and a party that have spent the last two days decrying the role of government in the private sector. It's an even more amazing when you consider that Ryan's running-mate opposed the auto bailout and even penned an op-ed titled "Let Detroit Go Bankrupt."

Ryan then quickly pivoted to the stimulus, which he described as "a case of political patronage, corporate welfare, and cronyism at their worst … What did the taxpayers get out of the Obama stimulus? More debt. That money wasn't just spent and wasted – it was borrowed, spent, and wasted."

As I wrote about a few days ago here, what the stimulus did provide taxpayers with was 2.5m jobs and an economic boost out of the worst downturn since the Great Depression. This is not to mention all the long-term investments in healthcare, transportation, infrastructure and energy innovation. To argue that the stimulus was wasted is just a breathtaking bit of dishonesty.

Then came Ryan's attack on Medicare. He lied about Obama taking money out of the program to pay for Obamacare. He lied about the fact that his budget has the exact same $716bn in cuts for which he attacked Obama. He vowed to protect and strengthen Medicare and honor its promise – even though his budget would end Medicare's federal guarantee and turn government-supported seniors' healthcare into a voucher program.

And perhaps most amazingly, Ryan criticized Obama for creating a bipartisan debt commission and ignoring its recommendations – recommendations that Ryan voted against as a member of the commission.

I could go on. The GOP has done more than create an alternate reality; they have built it on a host of political lies, misstatements and untruths. Ryan's speech was a good example of just how far the GOP has strayed from the truth – and of how debased our political discourse has become.

Michael Cohen is a US political columnist for the Observer and Guardian

Jim Geraghty: 'The bar is set extremely high for Romney this Thursday night'

It was a strangely imbalanced night in terms of quality: the early speakers were barely noticed by the conventioneers – even John McCain, who had some strong critiques of Obama's foreign policy – and worsened with a speech by near-veep Senator Rob Portman of Ohio (utterly forgettable) and other near-veep Tim Pawlenty (a seemingly endless stream of bad jokes, landing with one THUD after another). About halfway into Governor Mike Huckabee's remarks, it looked like the evening would be a cavalcade of bad-to-mediocre speeches, wondering if we needed even a third night to this abbreviated convention.

And then Huckabee got better, with some funny lines and some warm lines – best was, "I care less about where Mitt Romney goes to church than where he's going to take this country." But the unexpected grand slam was Condi Rice, who at first appeared to be speaking to check a few boxes: foreign policy speech, check; acknowledgement of the Bush administration, check. Instead, Rice offered perhaps the best speech on the country's problems since Lehman collapsed in late 2008, an acknowledgement that the country had stumbled badly and been bruised but was more than capable of picking itself back up and returning to greatness. It was a speech with vision, and the best of the convention.

So, the bar was set high for Paul Ryan; yet he cleared it – with a distinctly different, personable, more intimate style. He started out shaky, but watchers observed that the turning point was discussing his mother – and then he seemed to relax, and recognize that he knew the story he wanted to tell. Some funny lines will stay with us – the fading Obama poster on the unemployed grad's childhood bedroom wall – and I suspect all of the "granny-killing extremist" charges are going to have a much tougher time sticking, because Ryan seems so normal: even-keeled and warm and pleasant.

Wednesday night left two thoughts: one, the bar is set extremely high for Romney this Thursday night (remember, he's being introduced by Senator Marco Rubio, another one of the GOP's best speakers); and then … how do Democrats respond to this? Can they go negative and focus on tax returns and contraception and some Seamus jokes after the Republican message has been so focused, realistic, optimistic and bold?

Jim Geraghty is a contributing editor to the National Review

An Asian hacker group dubbed "Nitro", because its previous targets include chemicals manufacturing companies, was behind the first attacks to exploit a flaw in Oracle's Java software, says the security company Symantec.

Although little is known about the group, it is thought that they did not discover the flaw themselves but may have bought it from a commercial group that specialises in selling details about "zero-day" flaws in software that can be used to penetrate commercial or government systems, even when they have the most up-to-date cybersecurity in place.

"We can confirm that some of the attackers behind this latest round of attacks are actually the Nitro gang," Symantec says.

Orla Cox, senior manager for security response, told the Guardian that the gang had first been spotted online in October 2011, using a command server located in Singapore that was used to control the siphoning of information from 29 US, UK and Bangladesh-based chemical manufacturing companies, many listed on the stock market. She declined to name them, citing customer confidentiality.

The latest attacks, which have led to widespread advice that users should disable Java on their browsers, were spotted last week.

But Cox said that new evidence collected by Symantec indicated that the Nitro group was sending out targeted emails, again to chemicals companies, since 22 August – before the vulnerability was spotted by security researchers.

The emails contained a link which, if clicked, would take unsuspecting users to websites. Those then exploited the flaw in Java to load malware on their machine and leave it open to being surreptitiously controlled, so that information on it or its network could be siphoned to the gang.

"They haven't used a zero-day attack before, which indicates that they don't as a group have that expertise," Cox said.

She said that suggests that they acquired it commercially rather than discovering it themselves.

Zero-day flaws are a burgeoning commercial field in the underground hacker economy where some gangs work to order for commercial or government clients which want to break into systems.

Discovering them can take a long time and special expertise; deploying them tends to require much less skill.

Symantec said it could not identify the Nitro gang's location, as the Singaporean command computer could be controlled from anywhere in the world.

But it seemed likely, said Cox, that the gang is based somewhere in the region.

It is always good sport to tweak the noses of American religious fundamentalists, particularly at election time, and you can never say they don't need tweaking, as the revelation that some of Louisiana's schools are to benefit from remarkable textbooks indicates.

Under a voucher system introduced by the state's governor Bobby Jindal – a rising star of the Republican party – pupils attending 119 schools in the state, many of them run by the religious right, will be reading textbooks which tell them that dinosaurs co-existed with humans, slaves did not have it so bad and the Ku Klux Klan had some good points. Oh, and that Mark Twain was hopeless and Emily Dickinson, who spent much of her life shut up in her house in Amherst writing poetry, was presumptuous and disrespectful – both of them because they apparently had doubts about the beneficence of the Almighty.

These are from textbooks issued over the past few years by Bob Jones University in South Carolina, a bastion of segregationism and racial discrimination for decades, until it found it might lose its charitable status. It is more than a slight irony that this has come from a governor with an ethnic Indian background, who was a Rhodes scholar not so long ago at New College, Oxford, academic home of Richard Dawkins – the prof's head must be spinning that an alumnus is sanctioning science teaching that the Earth is only 6,000 years old in schools educating some of the most disadvantaged children in the US.

Walking with dinosaurs is bad enough, but what is particularly egregious is the shameless rewriting of history that is going on in some parts of the religious right. The Tea Partiers with their tricorn hats and fifes and drums propel a mythic past of the sort many nations comfort themselves with, but the Bob Jones textbooks with their assertions that "the majority of slave holders treated their slaves well" and the KKK "tried to be a means of reform, fighting the decline in morality" are not only absurdly, demonstrably wrong-headed, but take distortion to an entirely new level. Such tropes are fading even in the South, but it is not so many years ago that an elderly white woman in Natchez, Mississippi gravely informed me that of course, in the olden days, they treated slaves well "because, after all, they were our property".

More insidious still because of their veneer of scholarship is the work of the conservative historian David Barton, who tries to wrestle the nation's history into a Christian template that it just does not fit. His latest effort, Jefferson Lies, which attempts in the face of copious evidence to the contrary, to tug the Founding Father into the evangelical Christian tradition, was last month withdrawn from publication after being described as the least credible history book in print.

The surprising thing is that the publisher Thomas Nelson, which said it had "lost confidence" in the work, did not check Barton's track record earlier for he has quite – ahem – a history of that sort of thing. It was he who seemingly discovered a document by James Madison insisting that American institutions were founded on the Ten Commandments. Unfortunately the University of Virginia, which owns Madison's papers can find the fourth president saying no such thing, ever.

An especially ingenious effort is Barton's assertion that the delegates to the Constitutional convention in 1787 solved their deadlock by praying at Benjamin Franklin's suggestion: "While neglecting God, their efforts had been characterised by frustration and selfishness… only after returning God to their deliberations were they effective in their efforts to frame a new government."

Actually, what happened was that Franklin did indeed suggest praying, but the other delegates all opposed it, not least on the grounds that there was no money to pay a chaplain. Franklin himself wrote: "The convention except for three or four persons, thought prayers unnecessary."

That does not stop pictures by zealous modern artists, showing the convention on their knees, bathed in divine light, from gracing the walls of Christian right institutions such as Patrick Henry College near Washington, which prides itself on placing its students as interns with Republican congressmen. One even made it to be an adviser to the Bush administration in Iraq.

What makes this important is precisely that such falseness informs and is taken up by the Republican right to construct an image of the US and its constitution in its own likeness. Barton's work has been praised by the likes of Newt Gingrich and Mike Huckabee and notions like his insinuate themselves into the thinking of supreme court justices such as Antonin Scalia with their interesting interpretation of the constitution based on the founders' supposed original intent. Scalia says: "I look at a text. I take my best shot at getting the fairest meaning … understanding what it meant at the time it was adopted." This has implications for the definition of what the founding fathers understood by phrases such as cruel and unusual punishment.

Perhaps we should not be surprised that Louisiana school pupils may soon be taught that the hardships of the Great Depression were exaggerated propaganda, or that the laws of mathematics are a creation of God. After all, it's only 88 years since the legislators of Tennessee decided to outlaw the state's own biology textbook because it taught the theory of evolution and they didn't want their children getting the wrong ideas.

She would have been the perfect Paralympic ambassador for India – proof that a disability isn't a one-way ticket to a life begging at traffic lights or being shut up at home. The businesswoman and mother captivated the nation not known for its compassion for the disabled after she annihilated a bunch of able-bodied reality TV show contestants in a swimming race despite being paralysed from the chest down.

But Deepa Malik will not be competing in London – in the pool or on the athletics field, where she has been the Asian champion in shot put, discus and javelin. Despite her track record, she was not selected to be part of the 10-man squad. Emphasis is on the "man": this year, as in every single Paralympic Games that India has contested since 1968, there is not one woman in the team.

"It was a disappointment," admitted Malik, 41, of discovering that despite having regularly thrown beyond the qualifying distance for the B level of the F53 category in the javelin, her best sport, she had not made the cut. "For the last two years I've had my life on hold for the Paralympics."

She had already closed down her successful catering and restaurant business in order to concentrate on the 2010 Commonwealth Games, where she managed a sixth in the shot put. But, she said, "It's more about the journey than the destination" – and anyway, there's always Rio 2016.

David Premanath, a chief coach for the Paralympic Committee of India, said there was no conspiracy to keep out Malik or other female athletes. The fact was, he said, India received just 10 places from the London organising committee and was obliged to choose its 10 most promising athletes. "Even if 20 athletes qualify, we have to select the top 10 based on international rankings," he said. "In sports, there is no such distinction as men and women."

The fact that India – a country of 1.2 billion people – has just 10 places, none of them taken by women, shows how little support there is for the disabled, said Seema Baquer. She is the associate director of the Disability Rights Initiative at Delhi's Human Rights Law Network, which estimates that 70 million disabled Indians are "treated as second-class citizens and are forced to confront segregation, discrimination, barriers and stereotypes".

She said: "We find that the biggest problem is a general lack of awareness among families and communities about the capabilities and potential of people with disabilities. That support system – which realises that there's a still a lot they can achieve – is severely lacking. And even more so with women."

Women with disabilities were a "minority within a minority", she said. "There are a lot of barriers to the idea that disabled women can actually play sports."

Malik is uniquely well placed to change attitudes to disability in India after two barnstorming appearances on MTV's Roadies, a top-rated reality show which follows contestants on a road trip, completing challenges along the way. In 2007 she was shown on her specially adapted motorbike; earlier this year she was invited back on the programme, challenging contestants to a swimming race. Despite her opponents being allowed to wear life jackets, and Malik unable to use her legs, she wiped the floor with the lot of them.

Then there are the three records she holds in Limca, India's answer to the Guinness World Records: most notably swimming against the current for 1km in the notoriously filthy and dangerous Yamuna river, and becoming the first woman with her level of disability to ride her motorbike across nine high altitude passes in nine days from Leh to Ladakh in the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir.

Malik said there had been "tremendous change" in the 13 years since she became disabled after three spinal tumour surgeries.

There were now lifts for wheelchair users on the Delhi metro, for example, and new buildings had to be accessible since India signed the United Nations convention on the rights of persons with disabilities in 2007. But, she said, a huge social stigma remained: "There is still this pervasive religious view that if you are disabled, you have been cursed by the gods."

Henry Morris and I come from different ends of the socio-economic spectrum. Whilst at a top independent school Henry and his peers were encouraged to join clubs for aspiring accountants, lawyers and doctors – my comprehensive struggled to cobble together a woodwork club, let alone anything related to selective professions. By the age of 16, Henry had completed work experience at multiple top firms. One week at the local bike shop had to suffice for me.

Our backgrounds may have been different, but we met and became friends at university. There, we were struck by the contrasting aspirations and successes in clinching the elusive graduate job offer amongst our peers. To us, these different outcomes weren't all down to chance. Those from better off backgrounds, with the family contacts and parents who had "been there", were likely to be in with a better shot. Through no fault of their own, those from less privileged backgrounds at university started the race for top jobs later and struggled to catch up.

Our personal experience is one thing, but what about the evidence? Studies by Bristol University and others have shown that undergraduates from less privileged backgrounds perform at least as well academically as their more privileged peers. For example, at Bristol 88% of state school educated graduates received a 2.1 or above, compared with 85% of independently educated graduates. However, equal academic attainment is not matched by equal graduate outcomes; fewer graduates from less privileged backgrounds progress into the professions relative to their more privileged peers. They also tend to earn less; 3½ years after graduating, 33% of independently educated professionals earn over £30,000, compared to 14% of state educated professionals.

Whilst students do equally well academically, could it be that different levels of knowledge, soft skills, networks and professional experience explain the difference in graduate outcomes? This isn't a point about the recruitment process – we've come a long way from the outright bias in selection processes of the past. But what if our economy's top talent are not applying to the professions proportionally and when they do they underachieve against their potential?

The evidence shows that there are differences in the level of the key non-academic competencies required for access, and we know that the professions themselves are not socially representative. For example, whereas only 7% of the pupils attend independent schools, 54% of UK chief executives and 70% of finance directors were independently educated.

Reflecting upon our experiences, both Henry and I knew that there was a problem. Henry was acutely aware of the advantages he had in his journey towards job offers after graduation. For me, it was only through part-time work behind a desk at the university careers office that I really became aware of the breadth of career possibilities open to graduates of any discipline. Even then, this presented its own problem – how could I possibly make sense of all the different options available to me? The career-chooser computer software didn't really help either: despite my economics degree, one suggested that I should consider midwifery. The simple fact was that I had fewer sources of insight for advice on the careers that I was considering.

Inspired by the emergence of social enterprise and its commercial approach to making positive impact, we explored the issue further. The first stage was to develop a tangible idea of how we could make a difference. After researching third sector, government, university and employer programmes, it became clear that there is no overarching programme that supports students who have overcome the odds in reaching university to fulfil their career potential. Indeed, it looked like the impact of social background in the transition from university to professions was the least explored area of the wider equality agenda.

On the one hand, being at the forefront of this thinking was exciting – on the other, the challenges of explaining the significance of social background to employers was not always easy. Some were sceptical, suggesting that the barriers didn't exist and the fact that selection processes were fair was enough in itself. Others recognised that, in the battle for the best graduates, recruiters were missing out on top talent – many of whom will have demonstrated incredible resilience and adaptability just to get to university.

Universities quickly recognised that ensuring undergraduates from less privileged backgrounds fulfil their career potential was a natural extension of their widening participation efforts. Indeed, in the world of £9k fees, many universities have committed to this extension in their OFFA agreements.

Just a few months ago, both Henry and I had full-time jobs. Our time was limited, idea generation was slow, and developing new connections was painstaking. Soon our paths diverged.

For Henry, working full-time and developing our idea on the side was unsustainable. He left his role at a tech startup to focus exclusively on turning the idea into reality. For me, the practicalities of moving to London to get involved full-time were more problematic, I remain in my post at Exeter University and offer support from a distance.

Currently, upReach is engaging with employers, universities and policymakers to run a pilot programme in January 2013. We're honoured to have caught the imagination of influential leaders and are connecting with some of the UK's most prestigious graduate employers and universities. We've built a great team and are flourishing in our working environment, surrounded by an inspirational mix of founders and enterprises.

I genuinely feel that upReach has the potential and people behind it to make a real difference to the lives of thousands of students across the country every year. upReach's journey began with our experiences in the past, but now we're working for a future where social background is no barrier for undergraduates to fulfil their career potential.

Dale Potter works for the University of Exeter and helped Henry Morris found upReach – a social enterprise which aims to improve access to the professions for undergraduates from less privileged backgrounds. They will do this by bringing together employers and universities to run an on campus professional development programme. Twitter: @up_Reach

My friend George Balazs, who has died aged 92, was the former head of the BBC Monitoring outpost at Karen, near Nairobi. His death is a reminder of a whole generation of eastern and central Europeans who arrived on Britain's shores in the late 1930s and were snaffled up by the BBC. They were electrically intelligent and could speak foreign languages, even English.

George was born in Transylvania. His family's language was Hungarian, but, due to the rearrangements made at Versailles in 1919, his homeland had been made part of Romania. George spoke Romanian in the street and German to the staff. The family was Jewish but George did not make a lot of it, though it must have been an early sniffing of the fascist winds in 1939 that encouraged him to head west.

As a very young man – only 21 – he arrived as a student lawyer in England. Because Hungary was not in the conflict at that time, he was not drafted, imprisoned, interned nor sent back, but recruited by the BBC Monitoring Enterprise in Evesham, Worcestershire.

He made the BBC his life. Like so many of his central European compatriots he became part of that busy, chattering class that informed the Bush House newsroom and the Monitoring Service at Caversham, Berkshire, in the postwar years. None of these people were that easy to get on with. George, to say the least, could be testy. But he and they brought us culture, knowledge and life.

George's apotheosis was his appointment in 1972 as head of monitoring at Karen, where he had to control a motley crowd, which was listening to the feeds of radio stations from Ethiopia, Somalia, Uganda, the Congo and even Djibouti. French, Swahili, Amharic, Arabic, Persian and Somali (which in those days had no written text) swirled around the tiny collection of huts on the outskirts of Nairobi. From Karen, you could listen to the whole of the Horn of Africa, Yemen and even, on a clear day, central Africa. George, driving his orange Sunbeam Alpine to work every day, ran the show.

He never lost his love of east Africa. He stayed there, at the Nairobi Club, after retirement in 1980, as long as he could, visiting Kenya in later years on winter cruises when a minor stroke had confined him to barracks in NW3.

I last saw George at the Royal Free hospital in Hampstead, north London, not far from where he had spent the last 20 years of his life, walking daily on the heath. Despite macular degeneration, he knew every path and twig from his flat in Belsize Park, up to Kenwood House, and back again. In his hospital ward, from which he could look across the heath, the only item with him in those last days was his portable radio, tuned to Radio 3.

Ray Bradbury was investigated by the FBI during the 1950s, with government agents interviewing his peers and putting him under surveillance before concluding that despite being critical of the US government in his writing, the celebrated writer was never a member of the Communist party.

The 40-page cache of the late science fiction author's FBI files was obtained by the Daily Beast following a Freedom of Information request, and shows the extent to which the FBI had Bradbury in its sights in 1959. "Raymond Douglas Bradbury, a freelance science fiction, television and motion picture scenario writer … has been described as being critical of the United States Government," the FBI wrote on 8 June 1959, before laying out its issue with Bradbury's classic collection of short stories, The Martian Chronicles. The stories "were connected by the repeated theme that earthmen are despoilers and not developers", according to the FBI.

The FBI uncovered the information that "Bradbury has been extremely successful in the writing field". The bureau also discovered "that Bradbury, while a young man, sold papers and did miscellaneous small jobs", and that "in 1942 his writing were beginning to return him a descent [sic] livelihood".

A named source in the file, Martin A Berkeley, told the agents investigating Bradbury that the author "was probably sympathetic with certain pro-communist elements", and that during a discussion about whether Communist party members should be allowed to join the Screen Writers Guild, Bradbury "rose to his feet and shouted 'Cowards and McCarthyites' when the resolution was discussed".

Berkeley, a "self-admitted" former member of the Communist party, went on to tell the FBI "that science fiction may be a lucrative field for the introduction of communist ideologies", and that "some of Bradbury's stories have been definitely slanted against the United States and its capitalistic form of government".

Another informant agreed about the dangerous effects of science fiction, advising "that individuals such as Ray Bradbury are in a position to spread poison concerning political institutions in general and American institutions in particular", and that "Communists have found fertile opportunities for development; for spreading distrust and lack of confidence in America [sic] institutions in the area of science fiction writing". Even worse, "the general aim of these science fiction writers is to frighten the people into a state of paralysis or psychological incompetence bordering on hysteria which would make it very possible to conduct a Third World War which the American people would seriously believe could not be won since their morals had been seriously destroyed".

Bradbury did not help his own cause by taking out an advertisement in the Daily Variety in 1952, in which, according to the FBI documents, he wrote: "I have seen too much fear in a country that has no right to be afraid. I have seen too many campaigns in California, as well as in other states, won on the issue of fear itself, and not on the facts. I do not want to hear any more of this claptrap and nonsense from you. I will not welcome it from McCARTHY or McCARRAN, from Mr NIXON, DONALD JACKSON, or a man named SPARKMAN. I do not want any more lies, any more prejudice, any more smears. I do not want intimations, hearsay or rumour. I do not want unsigned letters or nameless telephone calls from either side, or from anyone."

Despite this, the FBI concluded in 1959 that "no evidences have been developed which indicate he was ever a member of the [ party]".

In 1968, however, it was investigating Bradbury again, looking into a potential trip by Bradbury to the Cultural Congress of Havana in Cuba, the purpose of which was "to obtain unity of action in the anti-imperialist fight". There appeared to be some confusion over the tip received by the federal agency, however: the named individual was one "Roy Bradbury", and after investigating Bradbury's passport file and lacking evidence that he had applied for or travelled to Cuba, it dropped the investigation, deciding not to interview the author. "Due to Bradbury's background as a known liberal writer, vocal in anti-United States war policies, an interview with Bradbury would be deemed unadvisable," an agent wrote.

Sam Weller, Bradbury's biographer, describes the FBI investigation in his book The Bradbury Chronicles. "I remember distinctly his response when I visited him and presented him with the files," Weller told The Daily Beast. "He beamed ear to ear and dismissed it with a wave of his hand and laughed and he said, 'I'll be damned, I've had nothing to hide over the years – what are they going to investigate? What a bore.'"

Relatives of British businessman Neil Heywood will not challenge Gu Kailai's suspended death sentence for his murder, a lawyer hired by the family said as the deadline for an appeal passed.

The wife of disgraced Chinese politician Bo Xilai was spared execution at a hearing last week, with a court in Hefei instead handing her the suspended penalty. Many saw that as unusually lenient for premeditated murder: unless she commits another crime while in jail, it will be commuted to life imprisonment after two years.

In China, crime victims and their families have five days to ask prosecutors to appeal against verdicts and sentences. Prosecutors then have another five days to take the matter to the court.

But He Zhengsheng, a lawyer hired by relatives of Heywood to represent them, said on Thursday that they had not contacted him to dispute the decision. He told the Guardian the judgement would therefore take full effect on Friday morning.

The businessman's Chinese widow has not responded to reporters' queries and his family in Britain have chosen not to speak to the media.

A spokesman for Hefei intermediate court said after Gu's hearing that the suspension of the death penalty reflected her regret, the fact she had given information about other people's crimes, and mental impairments she had suffered, which had weakened her self-control.

It also said she believed Heywood was a threat to her son, Bo Guagua, because he had made verbal threats to the young man. Friends of the dead man say they do not believe he would have done so and allege he was smeared to justify a lighter sentence.

Experts say a commuted death sentence usually leads to between 14 and 24 years in prison, and that Gu could be freed on medical parole in as little as nine years.

A family aide, Zhang Xiaojun, was jailed for nine years for the same crime. The court said his sentence was lightened because he was an accessory to the murder, not the instigator, and because he had confessed and shown remorse.

Lawyers for Gu, 53, and Zhang, 33, told the court during the hearing that they would not appeal against the judgement. Experts say there would be little point in them doing so in any case: the Communist party controls China's courts and such a sensitive decision would have been made at the highest level of the party.

The UK should delay its plan to kill thousands of badgers this autumn so experts can consider whether the cull is in line with a European conservation law, actors and celebrities have urged in an open letter to the government.

The pilot culls, designed to reduce tuberculosis in cattle, could be in breach of the Bern Convention that protects EU wildlife and habitats – despite being ruled legal by the UK high court this summer – argue signatories to the letter including actors Joanna Lumley and Dame Judi Dench, TV presenters Chris Packham and Mark Carwardine and author Jilly Cooper.

The secretariat of Bern said it believes there are grounds to consider whether the shooting of badgers by trained marksmen in Gloucestershire and Somerset as early as September breaches the convention, which the UK is a contracting party to, but its decision-making committee does not meet until November.

"The vast majority of available scientific evidence indicates that culling badgers … is not an effective way of controlling bTB [bovine tuberculosis] in cattle and can in fact increase incidence of bTB in some circumstances," says the letter.

It continues: "If, as it states, the government takes seriously its responsibilities to wildlife and respects the authority of the Bern Convention, it is logical that any badger cull be delayed until after the Convention has decided whether or not it might constitute a breach."

Since the environment secretary, Caroline Spelman, gave the green light in July last year for badger culls in England, the proposals have faced criticism from scientists and high-profile public figures including Sir David Attenborough. Campaigners have hoped that the government would back down after the Welsh assembly reversed its decision to cull badgers following strong public opposition.

Farmers and the government say the disease, which can be spread by badgers as well as among cattle, has become a huge cost to the industry. In 2010-11, nearly 25,000 cattle were slaughtered in England at a cost of £91m in government compensation.

In July, the high court ruled against the Badger Trust in a judicial review that challenged the legality – rather than the scientific basis – of the plan to cull badgers, clearing the way for the pilots to go ahead.

Humane Society International (HSI), which organised this week's open letter to Spelman, hopes it may stop large-scale culling by taking its battle to Europe.

Mark Jones, veterinarian and HSI's UK director, told the Guardian: "We believe that indiscriminately shooting these iconic creatures at night and potentially wiping out badgers altogether in some areas, must surely breach the convention. We're asking the government to have the decency to delay the killing so that Bern can properly consider the matter. With so many animals' lives at stake and in the face of such overwhelming scientific and conservation opposition, it would seem incredibly arrogant of the government not to do so."

HSI submitted its complaint to Bern in January, but it is far from a foregone conclusion that it will be successful in using the convention to stop the culls. Bern's bureau meets on 17 September and will decide on evidence submitted by the HSI and the UK government whether to refer the issue to its standing committee in November.

A spokesman for Bern said: "It would then be for the committee to decide whether there is a suspicion of a breach. It seems unlikely the committee would take a formal decision on whether to declare a breach – they would ask for it to be investigated further if there was a suspicion."

Badgers are listed as the lowest ranking of protected species under the convention – appendix III – which allows for species to be culled or hunted, provided certain methods are used and the "ecological characteristics" of the species are not affected.

A spokesman for the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs said: "Nobody wants to cull badgers, but no country in the world where wildlife carries TB has eradicated this devastating disease which forced the slaughter of over 25,000 cattle last year, without tackling it in wildlife too.

"Culling will only take place where it will help control this disease. The government will specify the maximum number of badgers that can be controlled in the area, and this will be monitored to ensure there is no local disappearance of them. The UK takes its responsibilities under the Bern Convention very seriously and we are confident our plans are consistent with its requirements."

• This article was amended on 3 September to change references in the headline and opening line of the story from the EU to Europe.

Good afternoon. The Guardian's rugby union correspondent Paul Rees will be online from 2pm BST to take part in a live webchat. If you have any questions about the forthcoming Premiership and Pro 12 seasons, drop them into the comments section below.

The Premiership season begins on Saturday, with a few Pro 12 games tomorrow evening. Here is a list of the weekend's fixtures:

Premiership
Wasps v Harlequins
Exeter v Sale
Gloucester v Northampton
Worcester v Bath
Saracens v London Irish
London Welsh v Leicester

Pro 12
Newport-Gwent D'gons v Zebre
Treviso v Ospreys
Ulster v Glasgow
Connacht v Cardiff Blues
Scarlets v Leinster
Edinburgh v Munster

2.00pm: Paul Rees is online answering questions in the comments section

2.08pm: LarryMilne starts us off with a comment about the Lions: "We all know what this season's building towards so let's not mess about – Lions starting XV for the first test, please." He also wants to know which teams will win the Premiership, Pro 12 and HEC.

Paul replies:

I will be boring with the Lions and say it will be based on this season's form, not the last one.

In the Prem, it is time Northampton stood up at the moment of reckoning. Despite losing Ashton, they look more creative behind but will need consistent direction at outside-half.

A bolter for the Pro 12: Ulster. As for the Heineken Cup, whoever beats Leinster in the knock-out stage.

2.12pm: HairBearHero asks about the "Farrell-Cooper Conundrum": "Which do you prefer in a flyhalf - mercurial moments of brilliance balanced by moments of farce; or reliability, solidity and occasional sparks of invention?"

Paul replies:

A 10 as slippery as mercury.

2.19pm: oconnope asks: "Do you agree with Mark McCafferty regarding the Rabo12 getting an easy ride vis a vis Heineken Cup qualification?"

Paul replies:

The principle of six teams each qualifying from the three leagues, supplemented by the winners of the Heineken Cup and the Amlin Challenge Cup, is fair and, commercially, such a move could enhcnace the Pro 12, more meaningful matches etc. That is the second hurdle for the French and English to overcome: the first is reducing the number of teams in the tournament from 24 to 20. As for sour grapes, if the HC were being dominated by Premiership and Top 14 clubs, they would not be complaining.

Another issue is whether the HC stands alone or complements the Six Nations. Would no Scottish or Italian involvement in the former weaken the latter? A potential compromise would be to reduce the number of teams the Pro 12 countries are guaranteed in the Heineken Cup, Ireland and Wales down to two from three and Scotland and Italy reduced to one from two.

2.22pm: gecko411 has a request: "Paul – please phone Heyneke Meyer and tell him his gameplan is outdated."

Paul replies:

His comment before the start of the Rugby Chmapionship that the day of the specialist open-side flanker had gone signposted the way they were going, although he seems to have had a change of mind!

2.25pm: RallyRoundTheRobins asks: "How did you celebrate the 117th anniversary of the formation of the 'Northern Union' yesterday?"

Paul replies:

By listening to Get Well Soon's new album.

This may or may not be the record to which Paul refers.

2.31pm: LarryMilne asks about the new rules: "Concussion bin, extended TMO, 5 second rule at rucks - think that's it."

Paul replies:

Concussion rule long overdue. As for five seconds at rucks, I hope referees say "out" when time is up. Not sure about the extended powers of the TMO. If the start of the two-phase movement is a scrum or line-out that should not have been awarded to the attacking side, the argument will go on. Football has long been going on about goal-line technology, but if a video official rules that the ball crossed the line only for the scorer to have been in an off-side position, or to have handled the ball, has the game advanced. I guess it is about minimising mistakes, not eliminating them. And the scrum will have no pause before a collapse.

2.35pm: Theboyspud asks about the relationship between Irish and Welsh rugby this year: "Do you think the Pro 12 final loss to the Ospreys and the almighty tonking we received in NZ will continue to affect Irish players?

Paul replies:

Ireland came close to the ABs in the second Test, far more so than Australia this month. No one would have lived with New Zealand in the third. Ireland's provinces are strong in Europe, Wales's regions are not, yet there is a gap between the countries on the international field.

2.38pm: Chemster asks: "Given that the Rabo Pro 12 is effectively a European League, could you see the Rabo countries forming their own European Cup and inviting disaffected French and English clubs to join them if the threatened Franglais boycott of the Heineken European Cup becomes a reality?"

Paul replies:

No. Premiership Rugby and Ligue Nationale de Rugby operate a three-line whip.

2.41pm: kwetemonkey asks about the ideal inside centre, giving these options:
1) Big, Bosh-merchant, good offloads (e.g. Roberts, De Villiers, Nonu/SBW)
2) Second Five 8, can kick and step in at first receiver, can release those outside (Carter, Sexton, Giteau/Barnes)
3) small, jinky, powerful, can create space for others (Darcy, Fofana)

Paul replies:

Horses for courses. Scott Gibbs was what the Lions needed in 1997. Watching Welsh rugby years ago, Nigel Davies and Alun Donovan were inside-centres I admired; not second-fives, although they could kick. They had vision, were composed under pressure and exploited those outside them to the full.

2.47pm: Developing on the theme of Irish and Welsh rugby, Chemster offers: "The Irish model has blatantly been the most successful in the Northern Hemisphere's domestic competitions in the last decade. The Welsh model has been the most successful in International competition. Perhaps the English and the French should be trying to emulate rather than castigate."

Paul replies:

They are coming at it from different angles. England and France are the only two major countries in the world that operate club tournaments. Ireland's players are centrally contracted and their leading provinces are effectively nationalised by the Irish Rugby Football Union; Declan Kidney tells his players when they can play, as is the case with the England and Wales Cricket Board. Wales are in between, having regions buit not central contracts, and the four are struggling financially with non-derby Pro 12 matches not attracting enough support.

2.50pm: MichaelVaughanMyLord asks: "What are the minimum number of wins each 6 Nations side should be aiming for this autumn?"

Paul replies:

Given the way South Africa and Australia have played this month, no honour in defeat there. The All Blacks are some way ahead, but it will be interesting to see whether the Rugby Championship sides rest players this autumn after what will have been the longest season for them.

2.53pm: RollandLeRat asks: "Is a Super Rugby style European league the only answer to the HEC shenanigans, and would it be good for playing standards in the Northern Hemisphere?"

Paul replies:

It would mean clubs in France and England having to concede sovereignty, which would only happen if they all went bust. The Top 14 is deeply ingrained in French rugby; they would not consider anything that threatened its supremacy.

2.58pm: UnderdogLife asks about the forthcoming Lions tour: "Any concern over Welsh Rugby Union involvement in the Lions given the hoodoo the SH currently holds over them?"

Paul replies:

No. Wales were heavily involved in the management of the 2009 Lions and Joe Schmidt would be an asset.

3.00pm: Peaceboy asks about the future of scrums: "There must be a better solution then just getting rid of them altogether. Which in my eyes would be a disaster (ex lock)."

Paul replies:

Better coaching and stronger refereeing. Collapsing by the side that fails to get the hit is too often connived at.

3.04pm: Hewerga22 asks: "How great a danger do you think there is of a Franco-Anglo breakaway from the Heineken Cup? And, do you think that they have a case?"

Paul replies:

The threat of a breakaway is a bargaining tool, but if Premiership Rugby feels the Heineken Cup playing field is not level, the French clubs have virtually double the salary cap of their English counterparts. It is, though, significant that the French Rugby Federation backed their clubs in giving notice to quit; under French law, clubs are only allowed to play in tournaments sanctioned by their governing body.

3.06pm: Rachel685 wants some predictions: "Do you have one for the Top 14? Why do you think the Top 14 has become so dominated by dull bosh-kick-repeat affairs despite the money and prestige of the French clubs, and do you see that changing any time soon?"

Paul replies:

Toulon look strong. As for style, has the French influence become too diluted? Toulon had only four players qualified to play for France in their first starting line-up of the Top 14 campaign. It has become and more disciplined and predictable league.

3.15pm: mattutes asks about London Welsh: "They were the fourth placed side in the regular season of the Championship and seem to be dead certs to go back down this season. These are not clubs that are hit by player call ups, so it's not like we need to soften out the pointy end of the season. Do play-offs really make sense? Should the top team just not go up? Secondly, they seem to be moving further and further west - they are now in Oxford."

Paul replies:

The play-offs are more of a challenge to the team that is relegated from the Premiership. Without them, the top flight had become like a 13-club tournament, with one having a year off.

London Welsh have dual membership of the Welsh and English unions, but their support is based in England and they have abandoned plans to play a match in Wales this season, taking two of their Amlin games back to Old Deer Park.

3.23pm: Hugotron wants an educated opinion: "How much rugby do you, or rugby journos in general, watch? Im hoping you will say "lots" and will therefore be able to clarify to the Rabo fanboys that the standard of rugby every week in the Top14 and Prem is unequivocally superior."

Paul replies:

They are different tournaments. The top sides in the Rabo would strengthen both the Top 14 and the Prem, but they would have to cope with more attritional campaigns. Similarly, French and English teams in the Rabo would need to play with more wit.

3.25pm: AndyinBrum asks about the obliquitous KP: "How do you think the Kevin Pieterson situation will affect Stuart Lancaster's planning for the autumn series?"

Paul replies:

Ban the use of mobile phones on the team coach and in the stadium, or go Bok to basics.

3.27pm: MrPerfect asks about Gloucester's chances under Nigel Davies: "He's not renowned for building a strong forward platform, and may suffer a little homesick being so far away from Tinopolis. Having said that, looking forward to their back play, may be good for England in time."

Paul replies:

He tried to build a pack at the Scarlets but lacked the budget to bring in top tight-five forwards and the emphasis there was very much on development. He is happy to delegate and it was time for him to leave Wales.

3.35pm: snoopster asks about the concussion rule, pointing out: "Brian Moore in the Telegraph was extremely critical of it."

Paul replies:

The hope is that a five-minute assessment will result in the medical team making the decision about whether a player carries on rather than, at the moment, coming under pressure from the stand with a team having to operate a player short.

3.47pm: LarryMilne wants some predictions about how the Irish teams will fare.

Paul replies:

Leinster have developed Munster's old knack in Europe of winning when below their best, away as well as home.

3.50pm: garbled asks: "Paul do you think English rugby will ever go down the road of regionalisation?"

Paul replies:

English clubs have invested too much to go down the regional route; the last time the RFU mooted the idea, it sank immediately. What they are arguing about Europe is that, commercially, they do not need it as it only generates 80 per cent of their income.

3.54pm: mattutes launches into a tongue-twister: "Should rugby twits tweet twattish stuff on Twitter?"

Paul replies:

A journalist is bound to say yes.

3.56pm: LarryMilne wonders what is exciting Paul: "What are you most looking forward to this season?"

Paul replies:

Good question. The November internationals will show how the four home unions are advancing tactically; or not.

3.59pm: LarryMilne asks about Gavin Henson and how the club game can influence the international game: "What role, if any, can the domestic game in the north play in helping close the gap between NH and SH? Is there much hope for us up here on that front?"

Paul replies:

I would like to see Henson get a run of games, but it seems he has booted every black cat on the planet in the last few years.

As for NH rugby, I would repeat what Sir Clive W said: there should be more effort put into individuals by coaches. Too many matches last season saw talent squandered.

4.03pm: snoopster asks about the chance of some the Welsh sides trying to join the "Anglo-French Cup": "I believe it was reported that two of them supported the French and English over the HC and they're unlikely to be happy about missing out on money as they would without the French and English?"

Paul replies:

Given the choice, it is something they would consider simply to attract spectators and increase revenue, but there is little chance of the WRU going with them.

4.07pm: HotspurPunk asks about the Spice boys of rugby: "Who will be more disappointing this season: Henson or Cipriani?"

Paul replies:

Cipriani has more to work with; Sale look to have a useful squad. I just hope the headlines they make are on the sport pages.

4.09pm: HotspurPunk asks about the 6 Nations: "What do you reckon England's starting 15 for the first match will be at this juncture?"

Paul replies:

November first. Decisions to make all over, not least half-back, midfield and back row. I would like to see Ben Foden used at full-back and the likes of Launchbury, Tom Youngs and Wade given a chance.

4.15pm: FugaziFan makes a point about the club v country debate: "The question is whether you really think it is right that nations with a long-standing rugby pedigree (Scotland) and nations that are at the forefront of rugby's expansion (Italy) deserve to be undermined and destroyed because English clubs want their power in the wallet to be more important than their ability on the field. I'd suggest if you think that is the case, you are not really a fan of rugby."

Paul replies:

Undermine the Six Nations and the income of the unions suffers. Is that an ulterior motive of the French and English clubs? The Champions League is an unashamedly commercial tournament, but it is all-inclusive, as the Heineken Cup has to remain.

4.19pm: kwetemonkey wants a definition to the word "attritional": "I'm not being funny, you hear this on here a lot but it's never defined. I think you are falling into the trap of believing the hype that somehow the Top 14 and Premiership are more difficult/tougher than the Pro12. What is your basis for this?"

Paul replies:

Attritional in the sense that every week is a battle. David Young, now of Wasps and once of Cardiff Blues, made the point earlier this month that in the Pro 12 you know you are going to get matches which are not going to be full on and that, round by round, it is far more up and down than the Premiership in which, he said, a team had to be on the money every week or it would get beaten.

I watch Pro 12 matches every week.

4.22pm: FugaziFan predicts an unpredictable season for Scotland: "Do you think it's inevitable that Scotland will beat South Africa and then scrape one home win in the 6 Nations?"

Paul replies:

They seem to have become more effective on the one-off occasion than in tournaments.

4.36pm: PintOfPlain asks: "What team do you support? What's your favorite ground? Best game you've attended?"

Paul replies:

Followed Cardiff before writing on rugby, so my favourite ground would have to be the Arms Park (not the Millennium Stadium). Best game from that era would be in the mid-1970s when Cardiff were 28-0 down to the Barbarians before a sell-out crowd and won with a late Gareth Edwards drop goal. There was nothing on what was annually billed as an exhibition game, but the result mattered.

4.45pm: laraxwell asks about the Ireland coach: "Irish Journalists have been loathe to go after the Ireland coach, despite a couple of poor 6 Nations seasons, a damning World Cup exit to Wales and a 60-nil defeat to NZ. I assume to do so would impact on certain privileges/accessibility to the Irish set up. My question is whether you might be willing to make a critique of the Ireland coach at this distance."

Paul replies:

The way Ireland lost in the last few minutes against Wales in this year's opening weekend of the Six Nations, blowing a lead having enjoyed a man advantage, was in stark contrast to the way Leinster and, before them, Munster managed games. I think this will be a defining season for Declan Kidney, especially as the IRFU has options in Schmidt and O'Shea.

4.48pm: mattutes asks: "Who will be Captain of the Lions?"

Paul replies:

Robshaw or Warburton.

4.50pm: twickersvicar asks about Danny Cipriani: "Will he play for Eng this season – or ever again – and do you think he should?"

Paul replies:

It will depend on how he plays for Sale and conducts himself. The position is not nailed down: it is up to him.

4.56pm: Thanks for your questions. Paul is off for a well deserved Assam tea. The comments section will remain open for the debate to continue.
